Why can't you answer the question of: why not review ALL of Israel's policies and adopt THEM, too? This appears to me to be someone defending their country and belief sets against a subtle attack on them. Personally, I don't care what or how other posters post. If I have a problem with someone, I speak my peace to them. However when I see a foul called on a play and am not quite sure why it was called it increases my curiosity and want for further guidance so that I will not make the same foul. No one wants a 10 yard penalty if they can help it.

title: Israeli Knesset To Consider Gay Marriage

content: .... and now this Israel OKs Right of Male Couple to Adopt The Tel Aviv family court ruled Tuesday that an Israeli man and his life partner may legally adopt their adult foster son. Uzi Even (pictured), a former Knesset member, and Amit Kama became the first gay male couple in the country to have their right to adoption legally recognized, according to the newspaper Haaretz. Even and Kama took in their 30-year-old son, Yossi Even-Kama, 14 years ago, after he was shunned by his biological family for being gay. The couple began adoption proceedings when Tel Aviv University, where Even is a chemistry professor, refused to give Even-Kama the tuition discount offered to families of faculty members. Law experts described the case as the first in which the right of two men to adopt was acknowledged in Israel, where female couples previously have been allowed to adopt. According to the verdict, a social worker who visited Even-Kama at home was impressed by the love and warmth observed among the family. >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74938.asp
reply: .... and now this Israel OKs Right of Male Couple to Adopt The Tel Aviv family court ruled Tuesday that an Israeli man and his life partner may legally adopt their adult foster son. Even and Kama took in their 30-year-old son, Yossi Even-Kama, 14 years ago, after he was shunned by his biological family for being gay. The couple began adoption proceedings when Tel Aviv University, where Even is a chemistry professor, refused to give Even-Kama the tuition discount offered to families of faculty members. Law experts described the case as the first in which the right of two men to adopt was acknowledged in Israel, where female couples previously have been allowed to adopt. According to the verdict, a social worker who visited Even-Kama at home was impressed by the love and warmth observed among the family. >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74938.asp

title: Israeli Knesset To Consider Gay Marriage

content: As to the first article your "source" didn't put these parts in, or reworded them nicely. "Horowitz said his plan would counter one put forward by Yisrael Beitenu head Avigdor Lieberman, which only applies to couples that cannot get married through the rabbinate, and will not include couples from the homosexual community." "Over the following weeks members of Knesset are expected to submit more than 4,000 bills. Many of the proposed laws will be submitted by the over 80 lawmakers which have held on to their seat from the previous Knesset. Many of those bills have already been rejected by the plenum in the past." and these parts I guess were also left out of the above, I guess due to lack of space? "But the viability of the bill remains in question. The Meretz Party holds only 3 of the 120 Knesset seats." "Only six countries allow gay and lesbian couples to marry. Sweden is likely to become the seventh in May." Horowitz is an openly gay "first termer" who is trying to push his agenda in the Knesset. Many people have come and tried the same thing and been rejected. The way your "source" has labeled it where "The Israeli Knesset is set to consider granting gay and lesbian couples the right to marry." may sound good but "consider is the key word and it seems like the Meretz party is the only one doing the considering. So I guess America is still right on track with the 188 or so other countries in the world and the around 185 other countries in the United Nations. As for as the next article. "Even-Kama moved in with Even and Kama at 16, after he came out of the closet and was driven out of his home because of his sexual orientation. "I grew up with both of my biological parents in Jaffa," said Even-Kama. "When I was 13 my mother and I escaped my violent father and moved to Rehovot, where she met another man. When I turned 16, I came out of the closet, and he had trouble accepting that." The same year, Even revealed in the Knesset that he was ejected from the Shin Bet security service when his employers discovered he was gay, after he had been working there for 15 years. "I decided to speak to the only homosexual I knew," said Even-Kama. "One day I went down to a public phone, all shivering, and called 'that professor from TV.'" When it became clear that his relationship with his family was not going to improve, Even and Kama offered the teenager the shelter of their home." Sounds like the same controversy happens in Israel that we have here in America. Plus HAARETZ is an extremist, agenda pushing news source that can not be taken as an unbiased, neutral source. I think it's funny, personally, that they publish an article about a gay couple adopting a 30 year old man and try to spin it, as if Israel is ready and paving the way for letting homosexuals adopt. The only thing all of this shows me is that with the current economic crisis, Israel dealing with the thought of exchanging 1000 terrorists in exchange for one of their soldiers in captivity, and the Israeli-Palestine conflict, the gay politicians care about one thing and one thing only, their agenda, and continue to push it as if it is the most important issue right now. In that America and Israel are very similar.

content: quote: Your comment or question as it is, has nothing to do with this thread. If you continue to be disruptive on this area of military.com I will ask that you no longer post here. This is the last warning from me. Next will be your removal from the G/L area. Mainedawg Moderator Maybe I am missing something here but when following this thread which was started with an outside link to an article, like many of these posts, which attempts to push an agenda and compare America to another country, which seems to me, to try to show that America is behind the times with our culture and ways of life. Then it is followed with this. quote: So, does that mean America is better, more moral and "Biblical" than Israel? What does it say that "Americans don't approve of gay "marriage"? and this quote: That's an answer? Then when the Christian cry we got our moral character from the Bible should we use all of the Bible for our moral character? Like slavery (which we did for awhile), stoning of gays, bad kids, adulterers, etc. Answer that and you'll know what my answer is. Which, as an outsider looking in, seems to say the same thing, that because we don't follow suit with other countries we are old school and laughable at best. It is hard for me not to see the relevance of a post containing a question which seems to follow suit with the customs and ways of other posters and their persistence on valid and invalid points. quote: Now you're just simply being unfair and picking & choosing a policy that supports YOUR agenda. Why can't you answer the question of: why not review ALL of Israel's policies and adopt THEM, too? This appears to me to be someone defending their country and belief sets against a subtle attack on them. Personally, I don't care what or how other posters post. If I have a problem with someone, I speak my peace to them. However when I see a foul called on a play and am not quite sure why it was called it increases my curiosity and want for further guidance so that I will not make the same foul. No one wants a 10 yard penalty if they can help it.

title: Israeli Knesset To Consider Gay Marriage

content: .... and now this Israel OKs Right of Male Couple to Adopt The Tel Aviv family court ruled Tuesday that an Israeli man and his life partner may legally adopt their adult foster son. Uzi Even (pictured), a former Knesset member, and Amit Kama became the first gay male couple in the country to have their right to adoption legally recognized, according to the newspaper Haaretz. Even and Kama took in their 30-year-old son, Yossi Even-Kama, 14 years ago, after he was shunned by his biological family for being gay. The couple began adoption proceedings when Tel Aviv University, where Even is a chemistry professor, refused to give Even-Kama the tuition discount offered to families of faculty members. Law experts described the case as the first in which the right of two men to adopt was acknowledged in Israel, where female couples previously have been allowed to adopt. According to the verdict, a social worker who visited Even-Kama at home was impressed by the love and warmth observed among the family. >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74938.asp

title: Israeli Knesset To Consider Gay Marriage

content: As to the first article your "source" didn't put these parts in, or reworded them nicely. "Horowitz said his plan would counter one put forward by Yisrael Beitenu head Avigdor Lieberman, which only applies to couples that cannot get married through the rabbinate, and will not include couples from the homosexual community." "Over the following weeks members of Knesset are expected to submit more than 4,000 bills. Many of the proposed laws will be submitted by the over 80 lawmakers which have held on to their seat from the previous Knesset. Many of those bills have already been rejected by the plenum in the past." and these parts I guess were also left out of the above, I guess due to lack of space? "But the viability of the bill remains in question. The Meretz Party holds only 3 of the 120 Knesset seats." "Only six countries allow gay and lesbian couples to marry. Sweden is likely to become the seventh in May." Horowitz is an openly gay "first termer" who is trying to push his agenda in the Knesset. Many people have come and tried the same thing and been rejected. The way your "source" has labeled it where "The Israeli Knesset is set to consider granting gay and lesbian couples the right to marry." may sound good but "consider is the key word and it seems like the Meretz party is the only one doing the considering. So I guess America is still right on track with the 188 or so other countries in the world and the around 185 other countries in the United Nations. As for as the next article. "Even-Kama moved in with Even and Kama at 16, after he came out of the closet and was driven out of his home because of his sexual orientation. "I grew up with both of my biological parents in Jaffa," said Even-Kama. "When I was 13 my mother and I escaped my violent father and moved to Rehovot, where she met another man. When I turned 16, I came out of the closet, and he had trouble accepting that." The same year, Even revealed in the Knesset that he was ejected from the Shin Bet security service when his employers discovered he was gay, after he had been working there for 15 years. "I decided to speak to the only homosexual I knew," said Even-Kama. "One day I went down to a public phone, all shivering, and called 'that professor from TV.'" When it became clear that his relationship with his family was not going to improve, Even and Kama offered the teenager the shelter of their home." Sounds like the same controversy happens in Israel that we have here in America. Plus HAARETZ is an extremist, agenda pushing news source that can not be taken as an unbiased, neutral source. I think it's funny, personally, that they publish an article about a gay couple adopting a 30 year old man and try to spin it, as if Israel is ready and paving the way for letting homosexuals adopt. The only thing all of this shows me is that with the current economic crisis, Israel dealing with the thought of exchanging 1000 terrorists in exchange for one of their soldiers in captivity, and the Israeli-Palestine conflict, the gay politicians care about one thing and one thing only, their agenda, and continue to push it as if it is the most important issue right now. In that America and Israel are very similar.
